VOL. XVIII, NO. 25.
OFF TO EAGLES MERE, PA.

• BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 4, 1914.

VIRGINIA WINS TRACK MEET
SCENES OF THE CONFERENCE AT EAGLES MERE

College Men's Camp Has Secured Noted
Leaders for This Year's Conference.
Hopkin's Delegation Active.

Eagles Mere, Pa., where the
Middle Atlantic Student Conference will be held this summer,.from
June 12 to 21, is on the very crest
of what we "lowlanders" would
call a mountain. It is, indeed, so
Close to the clouds that it takes a
little engine one hour to climb the
seven-per-cent, grade of the last
six miles; around and up it goes,
creaking and groaning, sometimes
along a steep ravine, at other times
beside the mountain falls, until it
finally reaches the beautiful lake on
the crest. Not far from the water
Hopkins has "its" cottage—every
delegation has a private house hidden somewhere back in the woods
surrounding the hotel. Fortunately,
the fellows do not have to cook their
own meals, but join with the two
hundred and fifty college men in
the hotel dining-room.
The conference is, of course,
basically a religious one. The men
who go have the ambition, as well
as the courage, to look the problems of life straight. in the face.
They are a superior class all around
—Miller of Penn State, Mott of
Princeton, Jimmie Patterson of
Pennsylvania, and numerous other
and well-known college men.
The morning of each day is spent
in mission study and Bible instruction classes. Professor Tweedy of
Yale will this year teach a class on
"The Student's Standards of Action" • Prof. L. H. Miller on "The
Manhood of the Master." In the
Opinion of those who were at Eagles
Mere last year, Professor Tweedy
is a leader of exceptional brilliance.
Besides these classes, Dr. Horne of
New York will have charge of Bible
leaders' training. On Sunday special meetings are held. John R.
Mott, the foremost worker among
students in the whole world, will
address several of these meetings.
Dean Shailer Mathews, President
W. .Douglas Mackensie, G. A.
Johnston Ross, T. Richard Glover
of England and George Irving, editor the North American Student,
are also among those who are to
speak.
Of course, a leading feature of
these conferences has always been
the opportunity to meet men of
other colleges—and meet them you
do! On the baseball field, in and
on the lake, on the tennis courts, at
track meets and, finally, on "college
night," men of like ideals, condition
and outlook make warm friendships
which are frequently permanent.

CARLISLE INDIANS SCALPED

BASEBALL MEN WIN AND LOSE

Hopkins Lacrosse Team Outwits Indians
at Their Own Game, and Astonishes
Them by a Shower of Goals.

Victory on Saturday Follows Defeat of
Thursday —Navy Again Victorious.
Delaware Goes Ten Innings.

Outplayed at every point, outwitted in every trick, the Carlisle Indians proved no match for the Hopkins lacrosse team at Homewood
on Saturday. The Carlisle team
has been pronounced the best aggregation in the United States, but
7 to 2 tells the story of their defeat by the Black and Blue players.
Carlisle came to Homewood confident of victory. Navy, who took
a game from us, had just proved
unable to defeat the Indians; and
so it was not until the game was
half over that the Indians awoke to
the fact that in us they had real opponents, but their awakening came
too late. When the final whistle
blew, the score stood 7 to 2 against
them.
The victory was not due to luck
or fluke plays. The Hopkins twelve

The baseball nine, during the past
week, added another victory and
another defeat to their record. On
Thursday, April 30, the Navy won
by the score of 7 to 3, white Delaware College met defeat on Saturday in a ten-inning contest to the
tune of 6 to 4.
The game at Annapolis was lost
because of four costly errors on the
part of our men. Silvester pitched
a good game, and had it not been
for the poor support his team-mates
gave him, the Navy, might have
been deprived of a victory. Silvester allowed five hits, struck out
seven men and gave only one free
pass. In the first, second and
seventh innings, the Hopkins nine
were guilty of errors at critical moments, with the result that runs accumulated on the Navy side of the

Hopkins Suffers From "Hard Luck" and
Takes Third Place—No Relay Team.
Georgetown Finishes Second.

llopkins had bad luck on all sides
of the track meet last week, and as
a result had to yield second place to
Georgetown. Virginia easily carried off first honors.
The heats were held at Homewood on Friday. As was to be expected, there was little real competition—the only object of the athletes being to qualify. Huntley
Lloyd, however, was accidently
struck by another's shoe, developing a bruised muscle on the right
calf. This injury gave him trouble
on Friday and kept him from equalling his usual performances on
Saturday.
In finishing the ioo-yard dash on
Saturday, Capt. "Ichabod" Wagner
sprained a tendon of his leg, which
precluded further participation. The
absence of Lloyd and Wagner necessitated the withdrawal of the
Hopkins relay team from the contest.
A strong wind was blowing from
the west, and the committee may decide that, on account of this fact, no
records can stand. Cronly, of Virginia, set new marks in the 120 and
220 hurdle events, while Connolly
made a new record for the running
high jump.
Wagner did the mo dash in io
seconds flat, beating Jones, of
Georgetown, by hardly a foot. Connolly won first place in the high
jump. Second places were captured by Tappan, Thom, Lloyd and
Lee, while Catlin, Tappan and Connolly won third places.
The summary tells the whole
story:

SOPHS WIN PUSHBALL CONTEST
They Showed Better Knowledge of the
Laws of Force Than the Freshies
and Shove Sphere More Easily.

Captain Leitheiser's squad of
sophomore pushballers was victorious over the freshman team on
Wednesday at \ Homewood Field.
The score was 70 to 10.
The second-year men showed decidedly better skill in pushing the
big ball and, probably because of
a better knowledge of the laws of
force, were able to tango it around
the ends of the fighting front of the
freshman line for two touchdowns
—each of which counted thirty-five
points. The freshmen scored ten
points by working the ball almost
down to the soph goal line, but they
did not succeed in getting it over.
The feat, however, gave them ten
points.
The contest was thrilling to the
players and immensely interesting
to the few spectators who braved
the weather. It was staged by the
Student Council to replace the traditional football game, which was
not played last fall because of the
lack of organization in the classes
following the hazing situation. It
was decidedly successful, and will
probably be played again next year
as an interclass affair. The big
sphere was borrowed from Wash-

ington and Lee, where the game is
traditional.
Just after the teams had gotten
into their gymnasium suits and had
been shoving the huge rhinoceros
hide around for a short practice, the
flood-gates of the ethereal regions
opened up and bedewed the halfnude athletes.
It was decided to start the game
at once, and to have four fiveminute periods witb short intervals
of rest for "second wind."
Promptly at five o'clock the first
whistle was blown and the game
was on. Twenty-five brawny lads
pushed the leather on either side
with such vigor that during the entire first quarter it hardly moved
more than ten feet either way beyond the center line. But it could
be seen that the sophomores had a
decided advantage.
With the beginning of the second
quarter, they attacked with a rush
and the resut was that within a few
minutes they had pushed the ball
down the field and across their opponents' goal. Score, 35-0.
The third and last quarters went
along in much the same way, the
sophomores scoring another goal
and the freshmen getting ten points
for having carried the monstrous
bulb the same number of yards into
their enemies' territory. The warriors of both teams were considerably battered up during the fray.

TURNBULL LECTURES BEGUN

OVAL IS TO BE MADE SMALLER

Professor George Lyman Kittredge Delivers First Lectures on Poetry of
Chaucer—Good Attendance.

Compromise Plan Approved by Board
of Estimates Tuesday—No More
Accidents Are Anticipated.

The nineteenth course under the
Percy Graeme Turnbull Memorial
Lectureship began on Monday,
April 27, at 5 P. M. in McCoy
Hall. The general subject of the
present course of lectures is: "The
Poetry of Chaucer." The lecturer
is Prof. George Lyman Kittredge
of Harvard. Professor Kittredge
gave the first three of his six lectures last week, and the last three
will be given on Monday, Wednesday and Friday of this week. The
subject of these lectures are given
in our University calendar.
Professor Kittredge is a most interesting speaker. His white hair
and beard give him a rather aged
appearance, and his vigorous and
forceful speaking and clear and distinct enunciation come as an agreeable surprise. The lecturer has an
impressive bearing and holds the
attention of the audience through-out the lecture. He shows that he
is thoroughly at home with his subject and never allows interest in
what he is saying to lag.
The first lecture was delivered to
a crowded hall on Monday, the
subject being "The Times and the
Man." Professor Kittredge gave a
very clear and comprehensive summary of the age in which Chaucer
lived and a careful outline of the
life, character and work of the poet.
The second lecture was on "The
Book of the Duchess," and the third
on "The House of Fame." At these
meetings, the lecturer gave very
concise and compact synopses of
these individual works, and a critical discussion of their literary significance and the place they hold
in the total of Chaucer's writings.
The, audiences at both of these lectures were large and attentive.

The compromise plan of reducing
the size of the raised oval "island"
in the middle of Charles street in
front of the new University was
approved by the Board of Estimates
on Tuesday.
Because of numerous complaints
made by automobilists and others,
as a result of several accidents that
occurred there, there had been considerable discussion over the "island."
The present "island" will be reduced to a blunt oval thirty-six feet
long and eighteen feet wide. The
plot will be ornamented with some
architectural embellishment, which
which will be augmented by five
white marble coping stones and
lights to guide drivers after nightfall.
The new plan, as approved by
the Board of Estimates, was prepared by Architect William W.Emmart for the City-Wide Congress
and provides for an uninterrupted
driveway on Charles Street Boulevard directly past the new "island,"
with a clear space of ten feet on
either side.

The 1914 Hullabaloo.

The appearance of the Hullabaloo
is expected some time this week.
Some delay was experienced at the
printer's, which caused the delivery
of the books to be postponed. For
this reason the time limit for the
advance subscription price has been
extended. The price of the book
will be two dollars, if paid on or
before Max' 8; after that date, the
book will cost two dollars and fifty
cents. The business manager has
announced that there will positively
be no repetition of last year's reduction of price, and that after the
time limit has expired every book
that is sold will cost two dollars
and fifty cents. Any member of the
Hullabaloo Board is ready to receive the two - dollar subscription
this week, and to give a receipt for
the amount. The books will be delivered to these subscribers immediately upon their arrival_ from the
printer.
It is reported that at one of the
Eastern colleges a professor advertised a lecture on "Fools." The
students flocked to hear the lecture,
and when they bought a ticket
found it was marked "Admit One."

sefiarattly at the Bookstore of JOHN H. SAUMENIC

PHI BETA KAPPA BANQUETS

CIRCUS TO BE HERE WEDNESDAY

New Members Initiated at Annual Feast
in Donovan Room Mr. Henry
Holt Delivers Address.

An Enterprising Press Agent Favors Us
With the Following Masterpiece
of "Main Tent" Advertising.

The eighteenth annual banquet of
the Alpha Chapter of Maryland of
the Phi Beta Kappa Society was
held on Saturday evening, May 2,
in McCoy Hall.
Just before the banquet, the twenty or so new members were initiated
into the Society and acquainted with
its secret signs and symbols. Mr.
Henry Holt, the. New York publisher, was received as an honorary
member of the Chapter.
The banquet was held in the
Donovan Room. About seventyfive members of the Society were
present to enjoy the ten-course feast
that was spread for them. Members of the faculty, "grads," medical
men, present and former students,
all joined in the enjoyment of the
annual affair. The Donovan Room
indeed presented an unusual sight
—instead of rows of chairs and
lectern, there were ten dainty tables
with candles and flowers. At the
east end of the room there was a
large electric sign formed of the
three Greek letters which constitute
the name of the Society.
After the banquet was over and
everyone's appetite was satisfied,
Dr. Bright introduced the speaker
of the evening, Mr. Henry Holt.
His speech was made on the subject on which he has recently published a large book—"Spiritualism."
Mr. Holt spoke of the legion of instances which force our belief in
ghosts or spirits of some sort. He
read numerous quotations from his
book, which tell of events which
cannot be explained as humbug or
farce. He spoke of the celebrated
medium, Mrs. Piper, and the extraordinary conversations that have
been carried on with spirits through
her. Mr. Holt declared that he
himself had some of the qualities
necessary for mediumship.
"The trouble with the age of today," he said, "is lack of reverence — lack of reverence for any
sort of superiority or attainment.
Why should we not listen with respect to accounts of spiritualism,
just because we are unable to explain them ?" Hr. Holt was asked
what he assumed as the explanation.
"I don't assume," he replied,"I only
guess."
After the address, Dr. Bright expressed the thanks of the Society to
Mr. Holt and assured him that his
speech had been reverently received.
Evidently, there are others, too, in
the world who are making investigations along these mysterious lines.
Dr. Bright reported that he had recently received a request for information as to -"How do you feel, and
what do you do, when you think of
nothing?" With a few closing remarks, the meeting adjourned.

be held in Oberlin on May 8 and 9.

An address on "The Three Functions of a School" was delivered
by Prof. Edward F. Buchner before
the Potomac Valley Round-Table
at Charles Town, W.'Va., on April
24. The round-table was the semiannual meeting of teachers, principals and superintendents of several
counties in West Virginia and
Maryland.
Dr. Flexner Given Cross of Honor.

Dr. Simon Flexner of the Rockefeller Institute, who was a fellow
in this University in 1891-92 and
who rose to the professorship of
pathological anatomy at the Medical
School in 1898, was given the Cross
of Chevalier of the Legion of
Honor by President Poincaire of
France last week in recognition of
his services to science and his assistance in supplying France with
anti-meningitis serum during the
epidemic of cerebro-spinal meningitis in 1909.
Dr. Flexner severed his connection here in 1899 to become director
of the laboratories in the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

May I, 1914.
To the Editor of Tilt NEws-Lvi-rER:
DEAR SIR—It seems to me somewhat lamentable that last fall's hazing incidents necessitated the abandonment — temporarily, I hope—of
two such old and delightful, yet
harmless, traditions as the class and
cane rushes. It is sincerely to be
hoped that next year will see the
ti iumphant reinstallment of these
two class events. But by that time
the present sophs will be eliminated
from the contests. Why need we
wait until next fall ? If the seniors
are going to follow the example of
the last two graduating classes and
have an athletic carnival at Homewood on the Saturday preceding
commencement, why could not two
freshman-sophomore events be included in the program? The final
exams will be over, and both classes
will be eager to get rid of their
surplus(?) energy. Moreover, the
sisters of the seniors will enjoy the
contests as much as they will some
of the antics which are usually perpetrated on the spectators on such occasions. Let the Senior Week Committee give this matter their attention; and, if the suggestion here
offered seems feasible, consult with
the presidents of the lower classes,
in order to bring about the resuscitation of these worthy traditions.

OFF TO EAGLES MERE, PA.

• BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 4, 1914.

VIRGINIA WINS TRACK MEET
SCENES OF THE CONFERENCE AT EAGLES MERE

College Men's Camp Has Secured Noted
Leaders for This Year's Conference.
Hopkin's Delegation Active.

Eagles Mere, Pa., where the
Middle Atlantic Student Conference will be held this summer,.from
June 12 to 21, is on the very crest
of what we "lowlanders" would
call a mountain. It is, indeed, so
Close to the clouds that it takes a
little engine one hour to climb the
seven-per-cent, grade of the last
six miles; around and up it goes,
creaking and groaning, sometimes
along a steep ravine, at other times
beside the mountain falls, until it
finally reaches the beautiful lake on
the crest. Not far from the water
Hopkins has "its" cottage—every
delegation has a private house hidden somewhere back in the woods
surrounding the hotel. Fortunately,
the fellows do not have to cook their
own meals, but join with the two
hundred and fifty college men in
the hotel dining-room.
The conference is, of course,
basically a religious one. The men
who go have the ambition, as well
as the courage, to look the problems of life straight. in the face.
They are a superior class all around
—Miller of Penn State, Mott of
Princeton, Jimmie Patterson of
Pennsylvania, and numerous other
and well-known college men.
The morning of each day is spent
in mission study and Bible instruction classes. Professor Tweedy of
Yale will this year teach a class on
"The Student's Standards of Action" • Prof. L. H. Miller on "The
Manhood of the Master." In the
Opinion of those who were at Eagles
Mere last year, Professor Tweedy
is a leader of exceptional brilliance.
Besides these classes, Dr. Horne of
New York will have charge of Bible
leaders' training. On Sunday special meetings are held. John R.
Mott, the foremost worker among
students in the whole world, will
address several of these meetings.
Dean Shailer Mathews, President
W. .Douglas Mackensie, G. A.
Johnston Ross, T. Richard Glover
of England and George Irving, editor the North American Student,
are also among those who are to
speak.
Of course, a leading feature of
these conferences has always been
the opportunity to meet men of
other colleges—and meet them you
do! On the baseball field, in and
on the lake, on the tennis courts, at
track meets and, finally, on "college
night," men of like ideals, condition
and outlook make warm friendships
which are frequently permanent.

BASEBALL MEN WIN AND LOSE

Hopkins Lacrosse Team Outwits Indians
at Their Own Game, and Astonishes
Them by a Shower of Goals.

Victory on Saturday Follows Defeat of
Thursday —Navy Again Victorious.
Delaware Goes Ten Innings.

Outplayed at every point, outwitted in every trick, the Carlisle Indians proved no match for the Hopkins lacrosse team at Homewood
on Saturday. The Carlisle team
has been pronounced the best aggregation in the United States, but
7 to 2 tells the story of their defeat by the Black and Blue players.
Carlisle came to Homewood confident of victory. Navy, who took
a game from us, had just proved
unable to defeat the Indians; and
so it was not until the game was
half over that the Indians awoke to
the fact that in us they had real opponents, but their awakening came
too late. When the final whistle
blew, the score stood 7 to 2 against
them.
The victory was not due to luck
or fluke plays. The Hopkins twelve

The baseball nine, during the past
week, added another victory and
another defeat to their record. On
Thursday, April 30, the Navy won
by the score of 7 to 3, white Delaware College met defeat on Saturday in a ten-inning contest to the
tune of 6 to 4.
The game at Annapolis was lost
because of four costly errors on the
part of our men. Silvester pitched
a good game, and had it not been
for the poor support his team-mates
gave him, the Navy, might have
been deprived of a victory. Silvester allowed five hits, struck out
seven men and gave only one free
pass. In the first, second and
seventh innings, the Hopkins nine
were guilty of errors at critical moments, with the result that runs accumulated on the Navy side of the

llopkins had bad luck on all sides
of the track meet last week, and as
a result had to yield second place to
Georgetown. Virginia easily carried off first honors.
The heats were held at Homewood on Friday. As was to be expected, there was little real competition—the only object of the athletes being to qualify. Huntley
Lloyd, however, was accidently
struck by another's shoe, developing a bruised muscle on the right
calf. This injury gave him trouble
on Friday and kept him from equalling his usual performances on
Saturday.
In finishing the ioo-yard dash on

sprained a tendon of his leg, which
precluded further participation. The

SOPHS WIN PUSHBALL CONTEST
They Showed Better Knowledge of the
Laws of Force Than the Freshies
and Shove Sphere More Easily.

Captain Leitheiser's squad of
sophomore pushballers was victorious over the freshman team on
Wednesday at \ Homewood Field.
The score was 70 to 10.
The second-year men showed decidedly better skill in pushing the
big ball and, probably because of
a better knowledge of the laws of
force, were able to tango it around
the ends of the fighting front of the
freshman line for two touchdowns
—each of which counted thirty-five
points. The freshmen scored ten
points by working the ball almost
down to the soph goal line, but they
did not succeed in getting it over.
The feat, however, gave them ten
points.
The contest was thrilling to the
players and immensely interesting
to the few spectators who braved
the weather. It was staged by the
Student Council to replace the traditional football game, which was
not played last fall because of the
lack of organization in the classes
following the hazing situation. It
was decidedly successful, and will
probably be played again next year
as an interclass affair. The big
sphere was borrowed from Wash-

ington and Lee, where the game is
traditional.
Just after the teams had gotten
into their gymnasium suits and had
been shoving the huge rhinoceros
hide around for a short practice, the
flood-gates of the ethereal regions
opened up and bedewed the halfnude athletes.
It was decided to start the game
at once, and to have four fiveminute periods witb short intervals
of rest for "second wind."
Promptly at five o'clock the first
whistle was blown and the game
was on. Twenty-five brawny lads
pushed the leather on either side
with such vigor that during the entire first quarter it hardly moved
more than ten feet either way beyond the center line. But it could
be seen that the sophomores had a
decided advantage.
With the beginning of the second
quarter, they attacked with a rush
and the resut was that within a few
minutes they had pushed the ball
down the field and across their opponents' goal. Score, 35-0.
The third and last quarters went
along in much the same way, the
sophomores scoring another goal
and the freshmen getting ten points
for having carried the monstrous
bulb the same number of yards into
their enemies' territory. The warriors of both teams were considerably battered up during the fray.

TURNBULL LECTURES BEGUN

OVAL IS TO BE MADE SMALLER

Professor George Lyman Kittredge Delivers First Lectures on Poetry of
Chaucer—Good Attendance.

Compromise Plan Approved by Board
of Estimates Tuesday—No More
Accidents Are Anticipated.

The nineteenth course under the
Percy Graeme Turnbull Memorial
Lectureship began on Monday,
April 27, at 5 P. M. in McCoy
Hall. The general subject of the
present course of lectures is: "The
Poetry of Chaucer." The lecturer
is Prof. George Lyman Kittredge
of Harvard. Professor Kittredge
gave the first three of his six lectures last week, and the last three
will be given on Monday, Wednesday and Friday of this week. The
subject of these lectures are given
in our University calendar.
Professor Kittredge is a most interesting speaker. His white hair
and beard give him a rather aged
appearance, and his vigorous and
forceful speaking and clear and distinct enunciation come as an agreeable surprise. The lecturer has an
impressive bearing and holds the
attention of the audience through-out the lecture. He shows that he
is thoroughly at home with his subject and never allows interest in
what he is saying to lag.
The first lecture was delivered to
a crowded hall on Monday, the
subject being "The Times and the
Man." Professor Kittredge gave a
very clear and comprehensive summary of the age in which Chaucer
lived and a careful outline of the
life, character and work of the poet.
The second lecture was on "The
Book of the Duchess," and the third
on "The House of Fame." At these
meetings, the lecturer gave very
concise and compact synopses of
these individual works, and a critical discussion of their literary significance and the place they hold
in the total of Chaucer's writings.
The, audiences at both of these lectures were large and attentive.

The compromise plan of reducing
the size of the raised oval "island"
in the middle of Charles street in
front of the new University was
approved by the Board of Estimates
on Tuesday.
Because of numerous complaints
made by automobilists and others,
as a result of several accidents that
occurred there, there had been considerable discussion over the "island."
The present "island" will be reduced to a blunt oval thirty-six feet
long and eighteen feet wide. The
plot will be ornamented with some
architectural embellishment, which
which will be augmented by five
white marble coping stones and
lights to guide drivers after nightfall.
The new plan, as approved by
the Board of Estimates, was prepared by Architect William W.Emmart for the City-Wide Congress
and provides for an uninterrupted
driveway on Charles Street Boulevard directly past the new "island,"
with a clear space of ten feet on
either side.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 4, 1914.
The 1914 Hullabaloo.

The appearance of the Hullabaloo
is expected some time this week.
Some delay was experienced at the
printer's, which caused the delivery
of the books to be postponed. For
this reason the time limit for the
advance subscription price has been
extended. The price of the book
will be two dollars, if paid on or
before Max' 8; after that date, the
book will cost two dollars and fifty
cents. The business manager has
announced that there will positively
be no repetition of last year's reduction of price, and that after the
time limit has expired every book
that is sold will cost two dollars
and fifty cents. Any member of the
Hullabaloo Board is ready to receive the two - dollar subscription
this week, and to give a receipt for
the amount. The books will be delivered to these subscribers immediately upon their arrival_ from the
printer.
It is reported that at one of the
Eastern colleges a professor advertised a lecture on "Fools." The
students flocked to hear the lecture,
and when they bought a ticket
found it was marked "Admit One."
Alumni of Harvard, Yale, Princeton and
Columbia. • One set of the histories of these institutions (full morocco binding,
4t0) formerly sold only together, will now be sold
sefiarattly at the Bookstore of JOHN H. SAUMENIC
& CO., 229 Park Avenue. A copy of the history of
Georgetown College (4to cloth) will also be sold
at the same place.

PHI BETA KAPPA BANQUETS

CIRCUS TO BE HERE WEDNESDAY

New Members Initiated at Annual Feast
in Donovan Room Mr. Henry
Holt Delivers Address.

An Enterprising Press Agent Favors Us
With the Following Masterpiece
of "Main Tent" Advertising.

The eighteenth annual banquet of
the Alpha Chapter of Maryland of
the Phi Beta Kappa Society was
held on Saturday evening, May 2,
in McCoy Hall.
Just before the banquet, the twenty or so new members were initiated
into the Society and acquainted with
its secret signs and symbols. Mr.
Henry Holt, the. New York publisher, was received as an honorary
member of the Chapter.
The banquet was held in the
Donovan Room. About seventyfive members of the Society were
present to enjoy the ten-course feast
that was spread for them. Members of the faculty, "grads," medical
men, present and former students,
all joined in the enjoyment of the
annual affair. The Donovan Room
indeed presented an unusual sight
—instead of rows of chairs and
lectern, there were ten dainty tables
with candles and flowers. At the
east end of the room there was a
large electric sign formed of the
three Greek letters which constitute
the name of the Society.
After the banquet was over and
everyone's appetite was satisfied,
Dr. Bright introduced the speaker
of the evening, Mr. Henry Holt.
His speech was made on the subject on which he has recently published a large book—"Spiritualism."
Mr. Holt spoke of the legion of instances which force our belief in
ghosts or spirits of some sort. He
read numerous quotations from his
book, which tell of events which
cannot be explained as humbug or
farce. He spoke of the celebrated
medium, Mrs. Piper, and the extraordinary conversations that have
been carried on with spirits through
her. Mr. Holt declared that he
himself had some of the qualities
necessary for mediumship.
"The trouble with the age of today," he said, "is lack of reverence — lack of reverence for any
sort of superiority or attainment.
Why should we not listen with respect to accounts of spiritualism,
just because we are unable to explain them ?" Hr. Holt was asked
what he assumed as the explanation.
"I don't assume," he replied,"I only
guess."
After the address, Dr. Bright expressed the thanks of the Society to
Mr. Holt and assured him that his
speech had been reverently received.
Evidently, there are others, too, in
the world who are making investigations along these mysterious lines.
Dr. Bright reported that he had recently received a request for information as to -"How do you feel, and
what do you do, when you think of
nothing?" With a few closing remarks, the meeting adjourned.

UNIVERSITY NOTES

AT OTHER COLLEGES

Professor Buchner Lectures.

Princeton will soon have a new
stadium costing $3oo,000 and seating 40,000 people.
* * *
Missouri has introduced a novel
course into its curriculum—a course
in ice cream making. All future
caterers and chefs in attendance at
the university are expected to derive much enlightenment from the
instruction received.
* * *
Five hundred Washington State
College students formed a parade,
built a bonfire and then burnt an
effigy of General Huerta.
* *
*
Western Reserve has received a
new endowment in connection with
its school of journalism—a recent
foundation.
* * *
"Safety first" is the new watchword of the University of Illinois.
* * *
The fifth annual meeting of the
Ohio College Press Association will
be held in Oberlin on May 8 and 9.
Twelve college papers will be represented.

An address on "The Three Functions of a School" was delivered
by Prof. Edward F. Buchner before
the Potomac Valley Round-Table
at Charles Town, W.'Va., on April
24. The round-table was the semiannual meeting of teachers, principals and superintendents of several
counties in West Virginia and
Maryland.
Dr. Flexner Given Cross of Honor.

Dr. Simon Flexner of the Rockefeller Institute, who was a fellow
in this University in 1891-92 and
who rose to the professorship of
pathological anatomy at the Medical
School in 1898, was given the Cross
of Chevalier of the Legion of
Honor by President Poincaire of
France last week in recognition of
his services to science and his assistance in supplying France with
anti-meningitis serum during the
epidemic of cerebro-spinal meningitis in 1909.
Dr. Flexner severed his connection here in 1899 to become director
of the laboratories in the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

May I, 1914.
To the Editor of Tilt NEws-Lvi-rER:
DEAR SIR—It seems to me somewhat lamentable that last fall's hazing incidents necessitated the abandonment — temporarily, I hope—of
two such old and delightful, yet
harmless, traditions as the class and
cane rushes. It is sincerely to be
hoped that next year will see the
ti iumphant reinstallment of these
two class events. But by that time
the present sophs will be eliminated
from the contests. Why need we
wait until next fall ? If the seniors
are going to follow the example of
the last two graduating classes and
have an athletic carnival at Homewood on the Saturday preceding
commencement, why could not two
freshman-sophomore events be included in the program? The final
exams will be over, and both classes
will be eager to get rid of their
surplus(?) energy. Moreover, the
sisters of the seniors will enjoy the
contests as much as they will some
of the antics which are usually perpetrated on the spectators on such occasions. Let the Senior Week Committee give this matter their attention; and, if the suggestion here
offered seems feasible, consult with
the presidents of the lower classes,
in order to bring about the resuscitation of these worthy traditions.

simply surpassed the Redmen in
every stage of the game. The Indians had their strongest force on
the field, but with all their craftiness they could not fool their opponents. In dodging, passing and
body-checking, tactics of which the
Indians are considered masters,
Hopkins excelled, and, with greater
speed and technical skill, rushed the
Carlisle men off their feet.
When the second half began, the
Black and Blue players started off
with a rush. Never has Homewood
seen better teamwork, quicker passing or more clever dodging. The
Indians seemed dumbfounded at
our evidence of skill. They tried
to rally and "did their durndest" to
stop the wave of defeat. But five
goals followed, without a single
scoring by the Redmen. Captain
Sutton and Huck gave the Indian
attack no chance for organization,
while Johnny Knipp, LaMotte and
Voshell refused to let the Indians
"cover" them, and neat passing and
excellent teamwork resulted in the
decisive victory for the Hopkins
team. The line-up and summary

The game at Newark, Del., had
a more pleasing outcome. For
seven innings it was a pitchers'
battle between Triesler and Delaware's left-handed twirler, Geoghegan. But then both seemed to go
up in the air, and each side scored
three runs, resulting in a tie-4 to
4. In the tenth inning Worthington
was hit by a pitched ball, Wilson hit
out a double and Lednum singled,
bringing in the two runs that won
the game.
When Delaware came to bat in
the tenth, the first two men hit safely. Then Silvester, who had been
substituted for Triesler in the
seventh, did "yeoman service" and
struck out the next three men up.
